title: 106_s148
content: The Act is titled the "Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act". Congress finds that approximately 500 bird species in the United States migrate among countries, with many neotropical migratory bird populations in decline, jeopardizing their long-term survival. These species provide valuable benefits to the environment, economy, recreation, and aesthetics of the United States and the Western Hemisphere. Neotropical migratory bird populations are declining due to habitat loss and degradation, posing a threat to their long-term survival. Conservation efforts require the commitment of all countries along their migration routes. Conservation of neotropical migratory birds requires international cooperation due to their migration across borders. Initiatives to protect these birds and their habitats can be more effective with increased coordination. The purposes of this Act are to perpetuate healthy populations of neotropical migratory birds, support conservation initiatives in the United States, Latin America, and the Caribbean, and provide financial resources for international cooperation. The Act defines "Account" as the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account and "conservation" as methods to ensure the long-term viability of neotropical migratory bird species through population protection, habitat management, research, monitoring, and law enforcement. The Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act focuses on protecting and managing bird populations, habitat maintenance and restoration, research, monitoring, law enforcement, and community outreach and education. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 5. FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. The Secretary will establish a program to provide financial assistance for projects promoting the conservation of neotropical migratory birds. Project proposals can be submitted by various entities including individuals, corporations, government agencies, and foreign entities. Entities eligible for financial assistance under this Act include subdivisions of States, municipalities, political subdivisions, entities subject to US or foreign jurisdiction, and international organizations. Project proposals must include the project leader's name and a brief statement of the project's purpose. To apply for funding under this Act, applicants must submit a project proposal that includes the project leader's name, project purposes, qualifications of project staff, estimated funds and time needed, and mechanisms for enhancing neotropical migratory bird conservation. The project proposal must demonstrate how it will enhance neotropical migratory bird conservation, ensure local public participation, consult with wildlife management authorities, respect cultural resources, and promote sustainability. The project proposal must demonstrate sensitivity to local historic and cultural resources, promote sustainable conservation programs for neotropical migratory birds, and provide necessary information for evaluation by the Secretary. Recipients of assistance must submit periodic reports as required by the Secretary. The project proposal must demonstrate sensitivity to local historic and cultural resources, promote sustainable conservation programs for neotropical migratory birds, and provide necessary information for evaluation by the Secretary. Recipients of assistance must submit periodic reports as required by the Secretary. The Federal share of project costs should not exceed 25 percent, and the non-Federal share must not come from any Federal grant program. The non-Federal share for a project should not exceed 25 percent and cannot be derived from any Federal grant program. In the United States, the non-Federal share must be paid in cash, while in foreign countries, it can be paid in cash or in kind. SEC. 6. DUTIES OF THE SECRETARY. The Secretary is required to develop guidelines for project proposals, encourage submissions from wildlife management authorities, select proposals that meet requirements and address conservation needs, and implement the Act accordingly. The Secretary must develop guidelines for project proposals, prioritize proposals that address conservation needs not covered by existing efforts, and are supported by wildlife management authorities, and generally implement the Act in line with its purposes. SEC. 7. COOPERATION. The Secretary shall support and coordinate efforts to conserve neotropical migratory bird species by facilitating meetings, promoting information exchange, entering agreements with other agencies, and conducting appropriate activities. The Secretary may convene an advisory group consisting of individuals representing organizations involved in the conservation of neotropical migratory birds to enhance conservation efforts. The Secretary may convene an advisory group representing organizations involved in conserving neotropical migratory birds. The group will hold public meetings allowing interested individuals to present statements on agenda items. The Secretary will convene an advisory group for neotropical migratory birds, holding public meetings for individuals to present statements on agenda items. The group must provide timely notice of meetings, keep minutes, and is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress by October 1, 2002, on the program's results and effectiveness under this Act, with recommendations for improvements and whether the program should continue. Establishment of the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account within the Multinational Species Conservation Fund of the Treasury to receive donations and appropriations for conservation purposes. The Secretary has the authority to use the funds in the Account without further appropriation. The Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account receives donations and appropriations for conservation purposes. The Secretary can use the funds in the Account without further appropriation, including for administrative expenses not exceeding 3% or $80,000 per fiscal year. Donations can also be accepted and used to carry out the Act. The Secretary can use funds from the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account for conservation purposes, including administrative expenses up to 3% or $80,000 per fiscal year. Donations can also be accepted and used for this purpose. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $5,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated annually for fiscal years 2001 through 2005 for projects outside the United States.
